DESSAC - DEcision Support System for Arable Crops
of Inhibition. Science, Art and Fungi
Pathogen Population Biology and Disease Management

This new programme (which commenced in April 2002) aims to identify common themes permitting fungi and viruses to attack wheat and the key plant components orchestrating defence responses. This has been achieved by functional genomic approaches, such as homologous recombination for fungal gene knockouts, Agrobacterium-mediated fungal transformation, fungal transcriptome analyses, exploiting diploid wheat, PCR Tilling to assess allelic diversity and by comparative wheat, rice and maize array experiments. Unusually, the group will focus equally on defining the function of both plant and pathogen genes. Understanding these systems at the cellular and the whole plant level will lead to new options for crop improvement and disease control.
New - Plant Pathology is not just for Christmas!

Principal staff involved: Kim Hammond-Kosack, Martin Urban, Alayne Cuzick, Sarah Lee, Chris Bass, Geoff Bateman (epidemiology and control), John Antoniw (bioinformatics), Arsalan Daudi, Kerry Maguire.

Fusarium species can invade cereals when they are flowering. The grain produced will then be of poor quality and may also contain mycotoxins, chemicals that are released by the fungus and which are toxic to both animals and humans. Objectives of our research include:
• Examining the molecular basis of plant defence to Fusarium
• Characterising the gene networks/pathways controlling in planta induction of trichothecene mycotoxins
<li> Pathogen characterisation: particularly the identification and characterisation of pathogenicity genes
<li> Disease control: the use of host plant resistance and biological control
Principal staff involved: John Keon, Jason Rudd, John Antoniw (bioinformatics)
Septoria leaf blotch, caused by Septoria tritici (teleomorph, Mycosphaerella graminicola), is consistently the most damaging leaf disease of cereals in the UK. Objectives of our research include:
<li> Pathogen characterisation: particularly transcription profiling and infection biology

<li> Epidemiology and control: crop canopy architecture has a major influence on the incidence and severity of disease. We are seeking to understand the interactions and to exploit them to decrease disease severity.
Principal staff involved: Mike Adams, Kostya Kanyuka, Chris Bass, Elaine Ward (Polymyxa), John Antoniw (bioinformatics)

Our work focuses on understanding and controlling the soil-borne mosaic viruses of cereals (especially wheat and barley). These diseases are serious in most temperate regions where winter cereals are grown and are not amenable to control by pesticides. They are transmitted by an obligate root-infecting parasite, Polymyxa graminis which is a member of the order Plasmodiophorales. Objectives of our research include:
• Virus-vector relationships: the use of molecular and cell biology techniques to characterise the association between the viruses and P. graminis
<li> Virus resistance: the detection, characterisation and exploitation of genetic resistance to the viruses
<li> Virus characterisation: particularly the use of molecular techniques to understand how viruses can overcome host plant resistance
• Vector characterisation: biology, molecular biology and epidemiology of P. graminis
<li> Use of plant virus sequence database for virus genome analysis and taxonomy: a more general interest extending to all plant viruses
Principal staff involved: John Lucas with Kerry Maguire

Eyespot is a fungal disease that invades the stem base of cereals, resulting in lodging and loss of yield. It is caused by Oculimacula (=Tapesia) yallundae and O. acuformis. The work in this programme aims to understand the factors leading to the production of the distinctive "plaque" structures that are formed between leaf sheaths when these pathogens infect.
Principal staff involved: Geoff Bateman, Richard Gutteridge

Take-all is a fungal disease (caused by Gaeumannomyces graminis) that attacks the roots of cereals, resulting in poor growth, premature senescence and loss of yield. It is the most serious and intractable of all cereal diseases. The work in this programme concentrates on integrated use of fungicides, as a basis for developing management strategies.
Principal staff involved: Kim Hammond-Kosack, Hai-Chun Jing

This is a more general interest that extends across all these pathogens and beyond. We contribute significantly to the UK Wheat Genetic Improvement Network (WGIN) and in particular aim to develop the PCR Tilling technology as a robust method for exploring allele diversity for diploid and hexaploid wheat.
Funding is from a Defra commission (AR0709) and a BBSRC JREI equipment grant.

This database contains expertly curated molecular and biological information on genes proven to affect the outcome of pathogen-host interactions. It can be accessed at: http://www4.rothamsted.bbsrc.ac.uk/phibase/
• EU CEREPAT project (Framework IV consortium on Cereal Fungal Pathogenesis)
A comparison of the infection biology of wild-type and single gene deletion strains of the wheat pathogen Fusarium graminearum - for details, follow this link.
Bioinformatics PhD Studentship: Text mining, data mining and database development in Bioinformatics- for details, follow this link.

We have a project to develop and exploit infectious clones of the barley mosaic viruses that is not funded but would provide an excellent opportunity for a suitably-experienced molecular virologist to apply for an incoming EU Marie Curie fellowship, or other similar funding. If you are interested, we would be delighted to hear from you! Please contact Kostya Kanyuka in the first instance.
